item.title: CodeClub/002 (20/9/16)
item.description:
Code Club 2 was a busy one! The computer room was packed, and it was a very hot day too!

Scratch game: Hide and Seek

This week we used Scratch to write a little Hide and Seek game.

Scratch is the most popular programming environment for primary school children. It allows you to build programs by dragging and dropping graphical blocks. This makes it much easier to learn about key computer programming ideas without having to type much, and without the annoying errors you get if you type programs as text.

If any of you think Scratch is a bit simple, think again! You can do some impressive apps with it, that would take much longer to develop in a traditional programming language. Check out these examples…

  • Whale: Control a swimming whale!
  • Picnic Smash: Don’t get any ants in your sandwiches!
  • Piano: Can you play a tune?
  • DJ Scratch Cat: A cat DJ?!!

The great thing is that you can look at and modify the code for any of these. It is very common for people to produce modified versions of other people’s programs - this is called ‘remixing’!

Have a go, and tell me if you create any remixes!

Tingbot

I talked a bit about Tingbot which is a cool little computer system based around a Raspberry Pi.

It is made by a small company in London who had the idea and raised the money to make it via the Kickstarter website.

It doesn’t have a separate monitor or keyboard like the computers in the computer room, but has a small built-in screen and a few buttons. Inside is a Raspberry Pi computer that can run Python programs that can read the buttons and draw pictures on the screen.

The good news is that I just got one this week, so once I have built it we can use it in future Code Clubs. Hurrah!

Python

To write programs for Tingbot, we are going to have to learn how to program in a language called Python. My favourite computer language! :-)

This is going to be more challenging than using Scratch. We had a quick vote at the end of the club and everyone said they were up for it, so let’s see how it goes!

Therefore… next week is Python Week!

item.title: CodeClub/001 (13/9/16)
item.description:
What a great first Code Club! I hope you all enjoyed it as much as I did.

This week we:

  • talked about why it is important and fun to learn about coding
  • looked at how computers have changed in recent years, and thought about how they might change in future (nobody knows!)
  • did some great programming of Minecraft and Disney Infinity Play Lab at code.org
  • had a play with my super-colourful NeoPixel LED strip, controlled by a Microview microcontroller and a Wii Nunchuk hand controller

I was really impressed with your enthusiasm and how much progress you all made in the programming exercises!

Code clubs

There are now nearly 5,000 Code Clubs across the country! Can you work out which circle we are in?

Computers are everywhere!

We talked about how computers are not just the things with keyboards and screens that are in the computer lab. There are now computers inside most electrical products: phones, TVs, cars, and even electric toothbrushes!

Soon all these devices will communicate with each other using the internet! This is called the “Internet of Things”

How computers have changed…

Early computers filled a whole room!

This was the first low cost home computer, produced by a British company called Sinclair.

This was the first computer I used in school. We only had one of them!

The first mobile phones were really big!

But have shrunk over the years…

And now have got bigger again! Today’s phones are incredibly powerful computers with a large super high quality screens and camera. This is probably 1000 times more powerful than the IBM/360 mainframe shown earlier!

The future…

No one knows what the future holds. Computers are still developing incredibly quickly. Will you all be doing school lessons using virtual reality headsets…?!

What I can say for certain is that computers will play an even bigger part of everyday life than they are now. So the more you know about how they work, the better!

I’m looking forward to seeing you all next week!

item.title: Welcome!
item.description:
Welcome to Abbey Code Club!

I’m very excited about our brand new code club - the first ever code club at Abbey School. I hope you are too!

There’s not much to read here at the moment, but I’ll be updating the website regularly so check back often.

Code clubs will run every Tuesday afternoon 3:30-4:30 in the computer room.

To get started, here are some links to websites that you might find interesting!

Code Club

Home of all Code Clubs. There are nearly 5,000 clubs in the UK!

Lots of projects here, some of which we will be doing in our Code Club. Most of these projects need a passcode to access them. If you are keen to try them out outside of Code Club then tell me and I’ll give you the required code.

Code.org

An American organisation, whose mission is to teach children to code. Sounds like a good place for us to go!

There are some great “Hour of Code” games here that are a fantastic way to get started with programming, including Minecraft, Star Wars, and Frozen.

Can you complete them all?!

You should also watch some of the videos - they have a lot of famous people in them, including Bill Gates (who started Microsoft), Mark Zuckerberg (who started Facebook) and Barack Obama (the USA president!). All of these people think it is really important for children to learn to code!

Scratch

The most popular way to write programs using graphical blocks. A great tool to start with. It means you don’t have to type very much, and teaches you the main principles of computer programming.

There are instructions on the right hand side of the page to help you learn how to use it!

Raspberry Pi

Everyone’s favourite low-cost computer. And it is British!

Have you got one?! If so, tell me what you do with it…

BBC micro:bit

A low cost “wearable” computer, recently released by the BBC (yes, the people who make TV programmes!). Check out the video.

Through the generosity of Code Club, we will shoortly be getting four of these, so I look forward to us using them later in the term!

If you want to get some practice in, you can follow a tutorial, write programs and run them on a “virtual” micro:bit here. Tip: it will easiest if you start off using the Block Editor!

Pimoroni

A British company who started off making cases for Raspberry Pis, but have now grown into making their own electronics, and selling all sorts of add-ons.

Designers and makers of the fantastic Flotilla electronics kit. I’ve got one of these, and we’ll do something with it later in the year!

Adafruit

American designer and maker of all sorts of cool electronic components.

Loads of great projects!

SparkFun

Another American maker of all sorts of cool electronic components! They have a large number of tutorials. Most of them are quite advanced electronics, but they might give you some ideas!

Make:

A very established American website that covers making all sorts of things - not just computer-related ones!

Lots of super-creative ideas here…!
